Article.ArticleTitle: Evaluation of Enhanced Ozone-Biologically Active Filtration Treatment for the Removal of 1,4-Dioxane and Disinfection Byproduct Precursors from Wastewater Effluent.

AbstractText: Ozonation followed by biologically active filtration (BAF) (O<sub>3</sub>-BAF) treatment has become an alternative to reverse osmosis in potable wastewater reuse applications because of the ability to produce a high-quality effluent while reducing brine production and disposal. In this study, effluent from a sequencing batch membrane bioreactor (SBMBR) was treated by O<sub>3</sub>-BAF at three specific ozone doses (0.5, 0.7, and 1.0 mg O<sub>3</sub>/mg DOC) and different empty bed contact times (EBCTs; 15-45 min). The reaction of O<sub>3</sub> with granular activated carbon (GAC) (O<sub>3</sub>/GAC) to promote the formation of hydroxyl radicals (·OH) was evaluated at 1.0 mg O<sub>3</sub>/mg DOC followed by BAF at 15-45 min EBCT. The efficacy of these techniques was compared for the removal of O<sub>3</sub> refractory 1,4-dioxane and the reduction in the formation of bromate, 35 regulated and unregulated halogenated disinfection byproducts (DBPs), and 8 N-nitrosamines after chloramination. Conventional ozonation (without the presence of GAC during ozonation) removed 6-11% of 1,4-dioxane, while BAF increased the removal to ∼25%. O<sub>3</sub>/GAC improved the removal of 1,4-dioxane to ∼40%, while BAF increased the removal to ∼50%. No bromate was detected during conventional ozonation. Although O<sub>3</sub>/GAC formed 12.5 μg/L bromate, this concentration was reduced during BAF treatment to <6.8 μg/L. Even though conventional ozonation was more effective than O<sub>3</sub>/GAC for the reduction in chloramine-reactive N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA) precursors, BAF treatment after either conventional or enhanced ozonation reduced NDMA formation during chloramination to <10 ng/L. O<sub>3</sub>/GAC was more effective at reducing halogenated DBP formation during postchloramination. Regardless, the reduction in halogenated DBP formation during postchloramination achieved by BAF treatment was ∼90% relative to the formation in the SBMBR effluent after either conventional or enhanced ozonation. The reduction of haloacetic acid (HAA) formation improved moderately with increasing BAF EBCT. Both O<sub>3</sub>-BAF and (O<sub>3</sub>/GAC)-BAF met regulatory levels for trihalomethanes, HAAs, NDMA, and bromate.
